statement: The method and experiments are limited to classification problems using models from the BERT family and GPT2, with experiments conducted primarily on text classification datasets which are relatively simple and similar in nature.
The applicability of this method to decoder-based models is not fully addressed.
The gradient-based methods are slow because they require many backward computations, and if the method requires too many computations, it is very hard to be applied in large language models.

This work lacks the comparison with causal-based methods, where an easier and faster method to identify important tokens is to replace each token with [MASK] and calculate the probability decrease of the predicted token.
Attributing at token-level is not enough for interpretability, and it is unclear if it is possible to identify the important inner parameters (e.g. attention heads/FFN neurons) using Contrast-CAT.
The method looks similar to AttCAT with minimal modification, where the only thing done was multiply the attention value to the conclusion from AttCAT without a reasonable explanation.
AOPC and LOdds results can be affected by many factors, including how to skip special tokens like [SEP] and [PAD] and how to 'remove' the important tokens, which could lead to different results.
The focus only on classification tasks is not exciting, and the research should at least discover more about text generation tasks.
For the contribution regarding filtering class-irrelevant features, it is unclear what the authors mean by 'class irrelevant' features.
